If you only have 1/2 of the slots machines open, and limit the number of people at table games, it could work. Likewise, shows could in theory run with 1/2 seats empty, though this may not be financially realistic. Much harder to figure out social distancing at night clubs.

With states, public health officials and even President Donald Trump weighing in on when the United States should lift social distancing requirements amid the coronavirus pandemic, a study authored by Harvard University researchers paints a bleak picture. The study, published in the journal "Science," suggests intermittent social distancing might be necessary until 2022 if no vaccine or pharmaceutical treatments for the novel coronavirus are found. "The total incidence of COVID-19 illness over the next five years will depend critically upon whether or not it enters into regular circulation after the initial pandemic wave, which in turn depends primarily upon the duration of immunity that SARS-CoV-2 infection imparts," the study said.

Social distancing is in place to keep those most at-risk for serious complications due to Covid-19 safe. If those people and the people who will be around them would stay home like they're supposed to, then social distancing wouldn't be required when/if casinos reopen. Unfortunately, all of these draconian measures are in place because those people would continue traveling if they weren't in place. That's why we are where we are now. Because of that, I'm betting when/if Vegas reopens, they'll start off by having slots set up further away from each other, and limits to the number of patrons who can sit at bars. The same will be true of restaurants as far as overall occupancy and table proximity. After an extended period of that, they'll probably start opening back up shows , pools, and nightclubs again, and then the final stage would be having everything go pretty much back to normal. Some sort of tiered reopen like that is what I see happening. No idea when, though.

I don't know the answer to this and a plethora of related questions. It seems managing compliance of distancing mandates in a casino environment ( we don't even know what those might be yet..will it remain 6 feet?) would be a logistical nightmare for those charged with enforcing them in real time. Add a few thousand deservedly fun-starved drunks to that scenario..I don't know how they accomplish it. That's not an intentionally negative take..seems like a really plausible problem, even without consideration of further spread, a potential second wave, all that. Regardless, it wouldn't likely make for a fun environment during a Vegas visit.

A few days ago I'd have said that if any casinos reopen without social distance requirements, it'd be those in South Dakota. But since news of a huge cluster in Sioux Falls, I think it'll be a long time before they reopen.I suspect casinos will be among the last businesses to reopen, as 1000+ room casino hotels = SARS CoV2 petri dish. They're like nursing homes on steroids in terms of opportunities for the spread of such a contagious virus. If the disease is still present in the country when they do reopen, it will be interesting to see if cigarette smoking is allowed, as I think that the virus can be aerosolized and spread in exhaled smoke. It's gross enough inhaling someone's exhaled cigarette smoke. But in this day and age, it might be too much to continue to put up with, from a public health standpoint.Whatever happens with smoking, I think casino floors will look much different, with machines spaced out and tables setup differently. Even if casinos don't close buffets, the days of self-service are over! It will be cafeteria style. No more sharing one serving utensil between hundreds of people. Bars and lounges will be set up differently, with more space between stools and lounge furniture. I could see there being some kind of virtual chips in the future, so that people wouldn't have to share them in playing the games.When casinos reopen, many people aren't gonna be able to afford to go to Las Vegas. Others might still be freaked out about the danger of catching the virus. So I doubt there will be a big rush and I think there will be good deals for players when things start up again. I miss casinos, but I'm happy to trade them for people not getting sick. I believe that closing them is saving lives. After we eradicate the virus, casinos will gradually come back to life. Until then, we have much bigger problems than closed casinos.

My bar has been closed for a while now. As much as I would like to re-open I can't think of a scenario where it would work with any social distancing rules in place. Another concern that applies to both bars and casinos, is that all it will take is one bad actor to make it all ineffective. Take Wynn. They released a 23 page list of restrictions they plan to have in place that might allow them to re-open safely. It'll be difficult, but it could work. I applaud their ethics in trying to strike a responsible balance between safety and turning a profit. But it will all be for naught if Caesars opens up and ignores all that. I see this happening everywhere. As for me, I'll risk financial ruin before I am a party to that.
